title: High-volume failed authentication attempts against windows-target-1 (credential spray / brute‑force)
description: Large clusters of LogonFailed events targeting numerous account names on windows-target-1 across multiple days and off-hours (2025-11-29 03:30 UTC, 2025-11-30 20:42–20:46 UTC, 2025-12-02 20:43–20:44 UTC). The attempts use many common account names (administrator, admin, user, etc.) from a wide set of remote IPs, consistent with credential stuffing / password spraying activity.

mitre.sub_technique: T1110.001 (Password spraying) / T1110.003 (Credential stuffing) — pattern consistent with password spraying across many accounts from repeated IPs
mitre.description: Attempting large numbers of logons against an account or many accounts using commonly used passwords or large credential lists to obtain valid credentials.

indicators_of_compromise: Usernames observed: administrator, admin, user, azureadmin, vpn, veeam, etc.
notes: Pattern: many different usernames attempted in short windows from repeated remote IPs — classic account enumeration/password spray. Confirm whether account lockout/MFA protections were triggered and expand search to other hosts for same source IPs.

title: Repeated failed logons originating from remote device 'win-agri80pj7cg' (possible lateral source / compromised internal host)
description: Multiple LogonFailed events to windows-target-1 list remoteDeviceName = win-agri80pj7cg and the same remote IP 45.135.232.96 across the 2025-12-02 20:43–20:44 UTC cluster. The presence of a remote device name indicates these attempts originated from another host in the network (possible internal pivot or a compromised workstation initiating remote authentication attempts).

mitre.sub_technique: Unknown (remoteDeviceName suggests remote service use — RDP/SMB/WinRM possible)
mitre.description: Adversaries attempt remote services to move laterally to other systems. Repeated authentication attempts from an internal host can indicate a pivot point.

indicators_of_compromise: Usernames observed from that device: administrator, vpn, ismarter1, caiwu, adm, admin, test1, user
notes: Remote device name present — treat host win-agri80pj7cg as high-priority for investigation: check that host for malicious activity, outbound connections, local successful authentication, running processes, and MDE alerts. If that host is an attacker-controlled jump box, they may be enumerating accounts internally.

title: No confirmed successful interactive user logon to human accounts in provided logs for the last two days
description: Within the provided log slice there are numerous LogonFailed events but only a small number of LogonSuccess entries tied to system/service accounts (umfd-0, umfd-1, dwm-1 on 2025-11-30 20:42 UTC). There are no LogonSuccess entries for human accounts (administrator, admin, other user names) in the supplied data.

mitre.description: No successful interactive user logon events were observed in the provided logs; however logs may be incomplete — verify full audit logs.

log_lines: No LogonSuccess entries for 'administrator' or 'admin' in the provided time ranges.
indicators_of_compromise: Successful system/service logons: umfd-0, umfd-1, dwm-1 (2025-11-30 20:42 UTC)
Absence of successful human account logons in the provided dataset
notes: This indicates no confirmed compromise of windows-target-1 (no successful human interactive logon) in the provided logs. However, the dataset may not include all authentication sources (domain controller/Security event logs) — verify Windows Security Event Logs (4624/4625), remote access/connection logs, and conditional access/AAD sign-ins to be certain.

title: PowerShell download of external payload and scheduled task persistence (initial compromise)
description: User kenji.sato executed a PowerShell-based dropper that downloaded scripts and binaries from an external IP (78.141.196.6:8080). The actor used certutil to fetch executables into C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache then created a scheduled task pointing to that dropped svchost.exe. Commands and parent/child process chains show clear attacker-driven PowerShell download+execution and persistence setup.

mitre.sub_technique: T1059.001 (PowerShell), T1105 (Ingress Tool Transfer), T1053.005 (Scheduled Task)
mitre.description: PowerShell used to download and execute scripts; certutil used to fetch binary; scheduled task created for persistence

log_lines: 2025-11-19 19:07:46.979651+00:00,kenji.sato,ProcessCreated,azuki-sl,"powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\Users\kenji.sato\AppData\Local\Temp\wupdate.ps1","schtasks.exe /create /tn "Windows Update Check" /tr C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache\svchost.exe /sc daily /st 02:00 /ru SYSTEM /f"
indicators_of_compromise: Scheduled Task: Windows Update Check -> C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache\svchost.exe
notes: The sequence shows a classic dropper: PowerShell download -> certutil fetch of binaries -> schedule task creation. Immediate containment is recommended.

title: Local privilege escalation / account creation and credential dumping (post-exploitation)
description: The attacker created a local account 'support' and added it to Administrators, then executed mm.exe with sekurlsa::logonpasswords indicating use of Mimikatz for credential dumping. These actions follow the downloaded payload execution and are consistent with post-exploitation lateral pivot and persistence.

mitre.sub_technique: T1136.001 (Local Account), T1003.001 (OS Credential Dumping: LSASS/mimikatz)
mitre.description: Local account created and added to Administrators; mm.exe invoked to extract credentials

notes: Local account 'support' added to Administrators — reset/disable immediately and review local and AD privileged sessions. Acquire memory image for LSASS if still available.

title: Data exfiltration via curl to Discord webhook
description: After obtaining credentials and collecting data, an outbound upload to a Discord webhook was performed using curl.exe, uploading a file from C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache. This indicates exfiltration of collected data to an external third-party service controlled by the attacker.

mitre.sub_technique: T1041 (Exfiltration over C2 channel), T1071.001 (Web Protocols)
mitre.description: Use of curl to POST a file to an external Discord webhook (HTTP-based exfiltration)

notes: Webhook URL should be treated as a confirmed exfiltration endpoint. Check firewall/proxy logs for additional connections to the IP and webhook.

title: Abuse of signed binaries / LOLBins (certutil, schtasks, net.exe)
description: Multiple signed Windows tools and common utilities were used to facilitate malicious activity: certutil to download binaries, schtasks to create a persistent scheduled task, and net.exe to create and add a local admin. This is typical LOLBin abuse to avoid detection.

mitre.sub_technique: T1218.010 (Signed Binary Proxy Execution - certutil), T1053.005 (Scheduled Task), T1059.001 (PowerShell)
mitre.description: Use of built-in signed utilities to download, persist, and execute malicious payloads

log_lines: 2025-11-19 19:07:46.979651+00:00,kenji.sato,ProcessCreated,azuki-sl,"powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File ...","schtasks.exe /create /tn "Windows Update Check" /tr C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache\svchost.exe /sc daily /st 02:00 /ru SYSTEM /f"
indicators_of_compromise: certutil.exe used to download svchost.exe / mm.exe
notes: These built-in utilities are abused frequently. Consider hunting for other instances of certutil/schtasks/net usage outside baseline times or by non-admin users.

title: Malicious PowerShell / Batch download and execution (initial compromise)
description: User kenji.sato executed a local WindowsUpdate.bat which used PowerShell to download and execute remote payloads from http://78.141.196.6:8080. Evidence shows certutil and PowerShell were used to retrieve EXEs into C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache and to invoke those artifacts. This sequence is classic initial access / execution via user-run script that retrieves remote payloads.

mitre.sub_technique: T1059.001 (PowerShell), T1105 (Ingress Tool Transfer), T1190 (Exploit Public-Facing Application) - (context: remote retrieval/execution)
mitre.description: Adversary used PowerShell to download/execute remote files (certutil & Invoke-WebRequest), transferring payloads onto the host and executing them.

notes: Download & execution originated from a user-run WindowsUpdate.bat. The remote host 78.141.196.6 should be blocked and investigated. The presence of files in C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache indicates persistence/storage of downloaded tools.

title: Credential dumping, account creation and persistence (mimikatz + scheduled task)
description: After downloading tools, there are commands consistent with credential harvesting (mm.exe sekurlsa::logonpasswords), creation of a local account 'support' and adding it to Administrators, and creation of a scheduled task 'Windows Update Check' to persist execution of the downloaded svchost.exe. This indicates active credential theft and privilege escalation/persistence by the operator.

mitre.sub_technique: T1003.001 (LSASS memory - Mimikatz), T1053.005 (Scheduled Task), T1136.001 (Local account)
mitre.description: Adversary ran Mimikatz-like commands to extract credentials from memory, created a local account and added it to Administrators, and scheduled a task for persistence.

log_lines: 2025-11-19 19:07:46.979651+00:00,kenji.sato,ProcessCreated,azuki-sl,"""powershell.exe"" -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\Users\kenji.sato\AppData\Local\Temp\wupdate.ps1","""schtasks.exe"" /create /tn "Windows Update Check" /tr C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache\svchost.exe /sc daily /st 02:00 /ru SYSTEM /f"
indicators_of_compromise: schtasks.exe /create /tn "Windows Update Check" /tr C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache\svchost.exe /sc daily /st 02:00 /ru SYSTEM /f
notes: Passwords are redacted in logs (*******). Verify presence of 'support' account, any created scheduled tasks, and the svchost.exe binary in C:\ProgramData\WindowsCache. Capture memory immediately to confirm LSASS dumping artifacts.

title: Data exfiltration and anti-forensic activity (Discord webhook + event log clearing)
description: Malicious script included an HTTP POST to a Discord webhook to exfiltrate data and executed wevtutil to clear Security/System/Application event logs. This indicates active data exfiltration and attempt to remove forensic evidence.

mitre.sub_technique: T1041 (Exfiltration over HTTP/S), T1070.001 (Clear Windows Event Logs)
mitre.description: Adversary uploaded files to a remote webhook (Discord) and cleared Windows event logs to hamper detection.

notes: Webhook URL and uploaded filename should be treated as confirmed exfiltration indicator. Preserve any outbound network logs and block the webhook address. Event logs may have been cleared — check centralized logging and repository for copies and collect forensic artifacts now.

title: Suspicious post-compromise lateral / remote access activity (cmdkey & mstsc)
description: Commands executed to store credentials (cmdkey) and connect to remote host 10.1.0.188 via mstsc, consistent with lateral movement or operator connecting outbound to remote systems using harvested credentials.

mitre.sub_technique: T1021.001 (RDP), T1110 (Brute Force / Cred usage - cmdkey used to store creds)
mitre.description: Adversary used cmdkey to store credentials and mstsc to connect to an IP (10.1.0.188), consistent with lateral movement and usage of harvested credentials.

notes: Investigate connections to 10.1.0.188 in network logs and check that host for suspicious inbound RDP sessions. Credentials used (cmdkey) should be assumed compromised; rotate relevant accounts and secrets.

title: High-volume failed authentication attempts targeting privileged accounts (probable brute-force/credential-stuffing)
description: A concentrated burst of failed logon attempts to device windows-target-1 between 2025-12-03 20:43:21 and 2025-12-03 20:46:53 UTC. Many attempts target high-privilege account names (administrator, admin) from a wide set of geographically dispersed IPs within a ~3 minute window — consistent with automated credential stuffing or brute-force. No successful logons are present in the provided DeviceLogonEvents for that period, but the volume and account focus indicate a real risk to privileged access.

mitre.description: Brute force / credential stuffing: repeated authentication attempts against accounts to obtain valid credentials.

notes: Volume, short time window, and targeting of privileged account names strongly indicate automated credential stuffing/brute-force. Validate with endpoint logs for any concurrent successful authentications, unusual process activity, or persistence.

title: Use of many variant and non-standard usernames (automation or account enumeration)
description: Log entries show attempts using many variations/localized forms of administrator (administrateur, administrador) and numerous odd/random usernames (?comodo, s+43mq, f1uyiejx, o3ts). These patterns are consistent with automated username enumeration or credential lists being tried against the host.

mitre.description: Credential stuffing / brute force: attackers try many username/password combinations, often including localized/admin variants and randomly generated names.

indicators_of_compromise: Usernames: administrateur, administrador, ?comodo, s+43mq, f1uyiejx, o3ts
notes: Localized admin variants and random-looking usernames suggest attackers are trying common privileged account names plus broader username lists. Correlate with authentication logs across other hosts to determine scope.

title: No evidence of successful interactive logon or lateral movement in provided DeviceLogonEvents
description: The supplied DeviceLogonEvents for windows-target-1 show only LogonFailed actions during the observed window; there are no LogonSuccess entries in the provided dataset. Therefore there is no direct evidence of successful lateral movement into/windows-target-1 from these records alone.

mitre.description: Attempts to move laterally require successful authentication; no successful authentication events are present in the provided logs to indicate lateral movement has occurred.

log_lines: All provided DeviceLogonEvents for windows-target-1 in the input are LogonFailed entries between 2025-12-03 20:43:21 and 2025-12-03 20:46:53 (no LogonSuccess lines present).
notes: Absence of successful logons in this dataset reduces immediate evidence of compromise, but do not assume the host is safe. Recommended to: (1) query for LogonSuccess events across full 24h, (2) check MDE process/network alerts on windows-target-1 around and after the attempt window, (3) verify account lockouts, and (4) block or rate-limit offending IPs if policy allows.

title: High-volume distributed failed logon attempts targeting 'administrator'/'admin' on windows-target-1
description: Between 2025-12-03 20:43:21 and 2025-12-03 20:46:53 UTC there are dozens of rapid LogonFailed events against windows-target-1 using highly privileged account names (administrator, admin). Attempts originate from many distinct external IPs and multiple repeated IPs, consistent with a distributed brute-force/credential-stuffing campaign. No successful logons are present in the supplied data, but the volume and diversity of sources indicate active credential guessing targeting privileged accounts.

mitre.description: Credential brute-force (repeated logon attempts using different credentials) — attacker attempts many logins to gain valid credentials.

notes: All events in supplied logs are failures; no confirmed successful authentication to this device in the given window. Rapid, distributed sources suggest automated tooling/botnet rather than a single compromised host.

title: Credential-spray / account-enumeration indicators: multiple localized and unusual account names observed
description: The failed attempts include numerous username variants (administrateur, administrador) and many distinct non-standard usernames (?comodo, s+43mq, f1uyiejx, o3ts, windows-target-) which is consistent with credential-spray or account-enumeration activity. The presence of localized admin names suggests either a broad spray list or automated attempt to discover valid account names across cultures/locales.

mitre.description: Password spraying — attempts using a small set of common passwords across many accounts and/or varied account name lists to avoid lockouts and discover valid accounts.

indicators_of_compromise: Usernames: administrateur, administrador, ?comodo, s+43mq, f1uyiejx, o3ts, windows-target-
notes: This pattern (many username permutations) increases likelihood of successful account discovery elsewhere; verify account lockout policy and check for any successful logons or related alerts across environment.

title: High-volume distributed failed logon attempts targeting administrator accounts on windows-target-1
description: Between 2025-12-03 20:43:21 and 2025-12-03 20:46:53 UTC there is a dense burst of LogonFailed events against windows-target-1. Attempts use common privileged account names (administrator, admin, administrateur, administrador) and many other user-looking names, originating from dozens of distinct external IPs. This pattern is consistent with automated credential stuffing / brute-force activity (multiple sources attempting the same/high-value account names in a short time window). No successful logons are present in the provided data.

mitre.description: Adversaries attempt to gain access by trying many username/password combinations (distributed/frequent attempts from multiple IPs) and by targeting common privileged accounts.

indicators_of_compromise: Usernames: administrator, admin, administrateur, administrador, demouser, ?comodo, s+43mq, f1uyiejx, o3ts
notes: Pattern shows many distinct external IPs and username variations in <4 minutes — typical of distributed credential stuffing or botnet-driven brute force. No successful logons in supplied data; check other logs (4624, MDE alerts) for successes.

title: No successful logons observed — potential for account compromise remains unconfirmed
description: The provided DeviceLogonEvents only contain LogonFailed entries for windows-target-1 in the examined interval. There is no evidence in these logs of successful interactive or remote logons that would confirm lateral movement or account takeover. However, the volume and targeting of privileged names increases risk; an undetected successful attempt could enable lateral movement or persistence.

mitre.description: Use of valid credentials to gain access. Failed attempts may precede successful authentication and use of valid accounts.

log_lines: All provided lines are LogonFailed entries for windows-target-1 between 2025-12-03 20:43 and 20:46 UTC (samples listed in previous finding).
indicators_of_compromise: No successful logon IOCs in supplied data — only failed attempts (see first finding for source IPs/usernames).
notes: Action is to search complementary telemetry (Windows Security event 4624/4625, MDE alerts, firewall logs, VPN/AAD signins) for any successful authentication from the listed IPs or using the listed account names. Verify account lockout/MFA policy and whether any privileged accounts have been used successfully recently.

title: User-created marker file 'Initializing Attack' (explicit malicious indicator)
description: A user-launched PowerShell_ISE/Explorer/Command sequence wrote a file containing the text 'Initializing Attack' to C:\Temp\Steal_Data\init.txt. This is an explicit, user-generated indicator of malicious intent and should be treated as confirmed suspicious activity. Parent process: PowerShell_ISE -> cmd.exe -> conhost. Timestamped activity shows a direct attempt to create artifact referencing 'Steal_Data'.

mitre.description: Command and scripting interpreter (PowerShell / cmd) used to create file and persist evidence of malicious activity

notes: File contents should be collected immediately. Check C:\Temp\Steal_Data for other files and timestamps, review user's interactive session and recent downloads.

title: Repeated PowerShell executions (DataCollection PS1) compiling code and running net.exe / auditpol (potential reconnaissance/automation)
description: Multiple system and service PowerShell executions point to scripts under C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\<id>\*.ps1 being executed (contexts: system, local service). These PS1 executions are followed by csc.exe compilation activity and repeated net.exe accounts and auditpol.exe queries. The sequence (PowerShell -> csc.exe -> cvtres.exe -> net.exe / auditpol.exe) appears automated and is consistent with scripted discovery (account enumeration) and possibly on-host compilation of tools. Some runs are under 'local service'/'system' and others under user context — investigate whether MDE sensor legitimately ran these scripts or if the DataCollection path was abused to host malicious scripts.

mitre.description: PowerShell execution (scripting), account discovery (net.exe), and audit policy interrogation/modification (auditpol) - possible reconnaissance and defense-evasion activity

indicators_of_compromise: PowerShell script path: C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\8809.14312662.0.14312662-98b468b9ed1cd00a611288a93e73b0baa9c0317b\*.ps1
Process owners: system, local service, aniket
notes: Caveat: PS1 files live in MDE DataCollection path which is normally used by the MDE sensor. Possibilities: legitimate MDE data collection behavior OR attacker placed malicious PS1 under that folder or abused the MDE execution mechanism. Pull the PS1 contents, check file hashes, validate with vendor telemetry, and correlate with network connections and user activity. Collect memory and persistent artifacts (SystemTemp cmdline files, compiled outputs in RES*.tmp).

title: Frequent 'wevtutil' manifest install/uninstall and MpCmdRun/wevtutil sequences tied to MsMpEng.exe (likely Defender update activity)
description: Large number of wevtutil.exe uninstall/install-manifest calls executed by MsMpEng.exe around 2025-12-05T03:08:15-03:08:20. This is consistent with Windows Defender engine/definition update activity installing event manifests. While wevtutil can be abused by attackers to modify event manifests, the observed sequence aligns with Defender component update (MpCmdRun.exe and MsMpEng.exe present).

mitre.description: Modification or interaction with event logging manifests — can be used legitimately by product updates or abused to tamper with logging

indicators_of_compromise: wevtutil.exe calls for manifests under C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender\Platform\4.18.25100.9008-0\
notes: This pattern matches Defender engine/definition update activity. Recommend validating against patch/update schedule and Defender service logs. Only escalate if there is evidence of tampering or unexpected account context.

title: LSASS memory dump and consolidated stolen archive created under C:\Temp\Steal_Data
description: A file named lsass.dmp was created in C:\Temp\Steal_Data followed by a stolen_data.zip archive in the same folder. Both files were created by the local account 'aniket' within ~1 minute — this is strong evidence of credential dumping and collection of sensitive material (LSASS memory dumps are a common sign of credential dumping tools). The zip suggests the operator packaged harvested data for exfiltration.

mitre.description: Credential dumping — LSASS memory dump (T1003.001). Creation of archive indicates collection/exfiltration of harvested data.

notes: Immediate containment is advised: isolate the host, collect volatile memory and process list, identify the process that produced lsass.dmp (parent process not included in provided logs). Check for outbound connections and uploads of stolen_data.zip. Preserve copies of the two files for forensic analysis and hash reputation checks.

title: Random-named DLLs dropped into temp directories (staging/unpacked payloads)
description: Multiple DLLs with randomized names were created under temporary locations (C:\Windows\SystemTemp\<random>\ and C:\Users\aniket\AppData\Local\Temp\<random>\). Examples include 21mox24t.dll, kldcnxkx.dll, bsrtkg2z.dll, fimbhdza.dll, ufywf0iu.dll and i5hed5ib.dll. Creation of multiple uniquely-named DLLs in temp folders — often twice in quick succession — is consistent with unpacking/staging activity by an installer or a malicious dropper. These files are outside standard system folders and should be investigated for possible execution, DLL side-loading, or runtime injection.

mitre.tactic: Persistence / Defense Evasion (staging for DLL side-loading or payload execution)
mitre.sub_technique: DLL Search Order Hijacking (possible staging for DLL side-loading)
mitre.description: Malicious actors may drop DLLs with randomized names to temporary locations as staging for execution or to facilitate DLL side-loading. Even if not used for side-loading, such artifacts indicate a dropped payload that warrants inspection.

notes: These temp DLL drops should be triaged: lookup hashes (where present) against AV/Threat Intelligence, determine the creating process (parent PID) and whether any processes loaded these DLLs (check module lists and Event Tracing). If any are confirmed malicious, quarantine and search other endpoints for same hashes. If legitimate installers are expected on the host (e.g., software installs), validate expected behavior; otherwise escalate.

title: User-created 'Initializing Attack' marker file (direct evidence of malicious activity)
description: A local interactive user (aniket) launched PowerShell_ISE and a command that wrote the string 'Initializing Attack' to C:\Temp\Steal_Data\init.txt. This is a clear, intentional indicator of malicious testing or preparation of an attack container on the host.

mitre.description: PowerShell interactive/script execution used to create an artifact indicating attack staging.

notes: This is explicit evidence of adversarial intent or testing by the local user account. Immediate host containment and live response collection (collect C:\Temp\Steal_Data, running processes, network connections, scheduled tasks, registry autoruns) are recommended.

title: PowerShell DataCollection scripts spawning net.exe / auditpol.exe (reconnaissance/defense discovery)
description: Multiple System / LocalService / user-invoked PowerShell executions ran DataCollection scripts from the Defender ATP DataCollection path and invoked LOLBins (net.exe accounts, auditpol.exe) and other system utilities. The pattern: powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy AllSigned ... C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\<GUID>.ps1 --> net.exe / auditpol.exe. This behavior can be legitimate (security/telemetry) but also matches reconnaissance (account and auditing enumeration) often performed prior to credential access or lateral movement.

mitre.description: PowerShell execution (T1059.001) launching system utilities (signed binaries/LOLBins - T1218) to perform account discovery (T1087) and gather audit settings (auditpol).

indicators_of_compromise: Processes: powershell.exe (many instances executing DataCollection scripts)
Paths: C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\<GUID>.ps1
User contexts: system, local service, aniket
notes: The DataCollection scripts are in Defender ATP's folder — these PowerShell launches may be legitimate telemetry or investigation activity by Defender components. However: the scripts executed net.exe and auditpol extensively (account and audit enumeration). Correlate with Defender/telemetry tasks, scheduled scans, and SOC actions. If not Defender-initiated, escalate.

title: No direct evidence of credential dumping (LSASS memory access) observed in provided logs
description: Search of the provided DeviceProcessEvents did not show common credential dumping indicators: no procdump/ProcDump.exe targeting lsass.exe, no rundll32 comsvcs usage for lsass, no mimikatz executable invocation, and no direct commands to 'tasklist /m lsass' or direct copies of lsass.dmp. There are many reconnaissance-like commands (net.exe, auditpol.exe), but no LSASS memory dump activity in the log set.

mitre.description: Credential dumping via LSASS memory or other stores. No direct evidence in these logs.

log_lines: No process create lines for ProcDump.exe, procdump.exe, mimikatz.exe, taskmgr-style LSASS dumps, or explicit LSASS handle dumps in the provided logs.
notes: Absence of evidence in these process creation logs is not proof of absence. Recommend live-response: check for LSASS dumps, scheduled tasks, autoruns, suspicious services, memory artifacts; review network telemetry for unusual C2 or data exfil patterns following the reconnaissance events.

title: No persistence mechanism created in observed logs (no scheduled tasks/registry autoruns detected)
description: Within the provided DeviceProcessEvents there are no clear TTPs for persistence observed: no schtasks creation, no 'reg add' autorun entries, no new services being registered, and no suspicious MSI or startup folder writes. There are legitimate system installers/updaters (Edge, Defender, Windows Installer activity) and sdbinst/appx installs which appear part of normal system/app updates.

mitre.description: No persistence artifacts (scheduled tasks, registry autoruns, new services) seen in supplied logs.

log_lines: No ProcessCreated lines indicating schtasks /create, reg add HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run, sc create <malicious service>, or similar persistence actions in the dataset provided.
notes: Although no persistence was detected in these process events, adversaries often use alternate persistence mechanisms (WMI, scheduled tasks run under SYSTEM, or leveraged signed components). Continue monitoring and perform file/registry live response if investigating the 'Initializing Attack' activity.

title: User-created marker file and direct shell activity — possible manual test or malicious actor
description: A user process (PowerShell_ISE.exe) spawned a cmd.exe which executed an inline command that writes 'Initializing Attack' to C:\Temp\Steal_Data\init.txt. This is direct evidence of interactive/intentional activity on the host by account 'aniket' and is a strong indicator of either an operator test or malicious action.

mitre.description: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell (cmd.exe) execution; interactive execution via PowerShell ISE is also visible

notes: The string 'Initializing Attack' is explicit and warrants immediate investigation of the user's session, surrounding commands, created files, and remote access sources. Check process tree, open network connections and any subsequent exfiltration activity from C:\Temp or the user profile.

title: Repeated account enumeration and audit policy queries launched from DataCollection PowerShell scripts
description: Multiple occurrences where a Defender DataCollection PowerShell script (under C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\...) invoked net.exe (accounts) and auditpol.exe queries. The parent process recorded is the DataCollection .ps1 executed by powershell.exe. Repeated net.exe and auditpol.exe calls are consistent with account enumeration and audit policy discovery — actions commonly used by attackers to discover accounts, domain configuration and to assess/disable logging.

mitre.description: Account discovery via net.exe (T1087) and audit-policy enumeration (defense-evasion reconnaissance to assess logging, T1562)

indicators_of_compromise: Parent PowerShell PS1: C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\*\a391f42c-7e1a-4611-8494-1817d2420e09.ps1
notes: The invocations originate from DataCollection PS1s (Defender telemetry). This can be legitimate telemetry collection, but the repeated enumeration of accounts and audit settings is consistent with attacker reconnaissance. Validate the content and provenance of the referenced PS1 files, check for modification timestamps, compare file hashes to known Defender files, and confirm these PowerShell executions are expected maintenance/telemetry tasks.

title: sdbinst.exe (shim database installer) invoked — potential application shimming persistence
description: sdbinst.exe was executed multiple times with -m -bg flags installing .sdb packages (sysMergeInboxStoreApp.sdb and similar). sdbinst is a signed Windows binary that's known to be abused for persistence via application shims. The observed usage could be legitimate appx/package work, but it is a known persistence vector and should be validated.

mitre.description: Abuse of application shims (sdbinst) to maintain execution/persistence

notes: If these sdb installs are related to normal WindowsApps deployment it's benign. Validate the specific .sdb files, their publisher/signature, creation/modification times and whether they were expected by IT/packaging processes. If unexpected, collect the .sdb files and create incident for deeper analysis.

title: Compilation activity via csc.exe from temp locations (signed binary used to compile) — possible LOLBin abuse for in-memory/compiled payloads
description: Multiple csc.exe invocations compiling from temporary cmdline files (C:\Windows\SystemTemp\* and service profile temp locations) with immediate cvtres.exe usage. Attackers have used csc.exe to compile and execute code on the fly to avoid dropping persisted payloads. These csc/cvtres calls are invoked as children of PowerShell executions tied to Defender DataCollection scripts in the logs — could be legitimate telemetry or an abuse pattern.

mitre.description: Command and scripting execution and signed binary proxy execution (use of signed compilers/CLIs like csc.exe to execute compiled code)

indicators_of_compromise: Parent PowerShell scripts under: C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\*
notes: This pattern is often used by legitimate security tooling (Defender datacollection compiles small helpers). Validate the exact ps1 and compiled sources' content and hashes. If those artifacts are not recognized as Defender/IT telemetry, escalate for deeper forensic collection (memory, compiled outputs).

title: LSASS memory dump and archive created in user Temp folder — likely credential dumping
description: A clear LSASS memory dump and an archive containing 'stolen' data were created under C:\Temp\Steal_Data by account 'aniket'. Creation of lsass.dmp indicates credential material was dumped from LSASS memory — strong indicator of credential dumping and data collection prior to exfiltration.

mitre.description: Credential dumping from LSASS memory (T1003.004). Presence of a zip named stolen_data.zip in proximity indicates local collection and staging for exfiltration (Exfiltration T1567/T1020).

notes: High-confidence evidence of credential dumping. Immediate escalation recommended: isolate device, capture volatile memory (if still available), collect endpoint process tree/network logs around 01:27:00-01:28:00 UTC to identify the creating process, and check outbound connections for exfil attempts.

title: Multiple suspicious randomly-named DLLs dropped to C:\Windows\SystemTemp
description: Several DLLs with short, random-like filenames were created under C:\Windows\SystemTemp in short succession (different subfolders). These are not typical Windows component names and frequently indicate an inbound tool/loader being staged. Creation account is 'system' for many entries, which can indicate a service or dropped payload executed by a system-level process.

mitre.description: Ingress tool transfer / staging of tools on host (suspicious DLLs placed in temporary system directories). Files in SystemTemp with random names are commonly used by loaders and post-exploitation frameworks.

notes: Medium confidence because temp/SystemTemp is often used legitimately by installers, but multiple randomized DLL names and folders are anomalous. Recommended actions: collect those DLLs for static/dynamic analysis (submit hashes), search for process creation and network activity around their creation times, and hunt for additional artifacts (services, scheduled tasks, registry Run keys, WMI persistence).

title: Frequent __PSScriptPolicyTest PowerShell module/script files created in Temp directories
description: Numerous files named '__PSScriptPolicyTest_*.ps1' and '__PSScriptPolicyTest_*.psm1' were written to C:\Windows\SystemTemp and user temp paths by 'system' and 'local service'. This pattern is typical of PowerShell script policy testing (benign), but frequency/volume is notable and could be used by adversaries to stage scripts.

mitre.description: PowerShell execution or staging of scripts (PowerShell). Many '__PSScriptPolicyTest' files indicate PowerShell policy/script activity.

notes: Likely benign PowerShell script policy tests, but because PowerShell is commonly abused, correlate with process execution and network connections. If these correspond with unexpected PowerShell processes or unknown parent processes, escalate.

title: LSASS memory dump and staged archive created (credential dumping / data staging)
description: A memory dump of LSASS (lsass.dmp) and a ZIP named stolen_data.zip were created under C:\Temp\Steal_Data by account 'aniket'. A direct LSASS dump is a canonical credential-dumping artifact and the subsequent ZIP indicates staging of stolen credentials/data for exfiltration.

mitre.sub_technique: T1003 (LSASS Memory) ; T1005 (Data from Local System) ; T1041 (Exfiltration Over C2 - potential)
mitre.description: T1003: Credential dumping from LSASS memory. T1005: collection of data from local system. T1041: staged data indicates potential exfiltration (no network egress record in file logs).

notes: Direct LSASS dump and zipped archive created by user 'aniket'. Recommend immediate containment of the device, collection of volatile evidence (memory, running processes, network connections), and search for network uploads of stolen_data.zip or other egress events.

title: Multiple suspicious DLL drops into C:\Windows\SystemTemp\<random> directories
description: Several non-standard DLLs with randomized-looking names were created under C:\Windows\SystemTemp\<random> directories (e.g., 21mox24t.dll, kldcnxkx.dll, bsrtkg2z.dll, fimbhdza.dll, i5hed5ib.dll, ufywf0iu.dll). These look like dropped payloads; creation under SystemTemp with many distinct random names is consistent with malware staging or lateral tool deployment and can be used for persistence or runtime module loading.

mitre.sub_technique: T1547 (Boot or Logon Autostart Persistence) — potential; T1497 (Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion) — tactic related to use of temp staging
mitre.description: Suspicious binary drops in system temp directories are commonly used to stage payloads, install services, or perform process injection; observed activity is indicative of potential persistence or malware staging (no explicit autostart registration observed in logs).

notes: No explicit autostart registration (services / scheduled tasks / registry) observed in this file log set — further investigation required (persisting artifacts, service creation, scheduled tasks, autoruns). Hunt for process loads using these DLLs, parent processes that created them, and registry/startup entries.

title: High-volume PowerShell policy-test script files created in Temp locations
description: Many __PSScriptPolicyTest_*.ps1 and .psm1 files were created under C:\Windows\SystemTemp and C:\Windows\ServiceProfiles\LocalService\AppData\Local\Temp as 'system' or 'local service'. While these can be benign (PowerShell policy checks/engine behavior), the volume and frequency together with other suspicious activity (LSASS dump and random DLL drops) warrant review for interactive or scripted PowerShell usage that may have been used to drop payloads or run credential-dump tools.

mitre.description: PowerShell used to execute scripts. Numerous temporary PowerShell module/script files written to Temp locations can indicate scripted execution or automated tool activity.

notes: These files may be legitimate PowerShell policy test artifacts. Correlate with PowerShell process command lines, parent processes, signed/untrusted scripts, and timestamps around the LSASS dump to determine if they were used in malicious activity.

title: LSASS memory dump and archive created under C:\Temp\Steal_Data (likely credential dumping)
description: Two files that look like stolen credential artifacts were created by user 'aniket' in C:\Temp\Steal_Data within ~1 minute: lsass.dmp (LSASS memory dump) and stolen_data.zip. Creation of an LSASS dump and a ZIP named 'stolen_data' is highly suspicious for credential access and data staging/exfiltration.

mitre.description: T1003: Credential dumping from LSASS memory. T1041: Exfiltration over C2 or staging to compressed archive for exfiltration.

notes: No DeviceProcessEvents provided to show the process that generated these files. Next step: pull process creation/parent chain, network activity for related timestamps, and EDR telemetry for commands that export LSASS (e.g., procdump, rundll32+comsvcs.dll, Mimikatz).

title: Multiple randomly-named DLLs dropped to C:\Windows\SystemTemp (potential unpacked payloads / side-loading)
description: Several DLLs with short/random names were created in C:\Windows\SystemTemp\<random folder> (e.g., 21mox24t.dll, kldcnxkx.dll, bsrtkg2z.dll, fimbhdza.dll, ufywf0iu.dll, i5hed5ib.dll). Random-named DLLs appearing in SystemTemp are commonly observed when malware unpacks payloads before execution or attempts DLL side-loading. These drops merit investigation for persistence or execution attempts.

mitre.sub_technique: T1574 (Hijack Execution Flow) — DLL side-loading / temporary DLL drops
mitre.description: Adversaries may drop DLLs to disk (often in temp directories) and leverage execution flow hijacks or loader behavior to execute them. Randomized names and placement in SystemTemp is suspicious.

indicators_of_compromise: Creation times vary between 2025-12-05 01:20 and 06:58 UTC
notes: No process execution evidence included. Recommended next steps: query DeviceProcessEvents for processes that wrote/loaded these DLLs and query ImageLoad / ModuleLoad events to see if any were mapped into memory. Also check Autoruns, scheduled tasks, services, and run keys for anchors using these files.

title: Large volume of '__PSScriptPolicyTest_*.ps1/psm1' files created in temp paths (PowerShell policy tests)
description: Numerous files named __PSScriptPolicyTest_*.ps1 and *.psm1 were created under C:\Windows\SystemTemp and service profile temp folders and some under the user's Temp. These are commonly produced by PowerShell's script policy/testing operations (benign), but the repeated/continuous creation across multiple time windows could also be leveraged by malicious scripts dropping helpers into temp locations. At present they appear consistent with PowerShell policy test artifacts.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use PowerShell to execute code or drop scripts. Temporary PowerShell module/script files in SystemTemp or user temp are common for both benign and malicious activity.

indicators_of_compromise: Multiple __PSScriptPolicyTest_*.ps1 and __PSScriptPolicyTest_*.psm1 files under C:\Windows\SystemTemp and C:\Windows\ServiceProfiles\LocalService\AppData\Local\Temp
notes: These file names match PowerShell script policy test artifacts and may be benign. Correlate with PowerShell process command lines, script block logging, module loads, and parent processes to rule out malicious use. If correlated with lsass.dmp creation or the DLL drops above, escalate.

title: Frequent PowerShell executions from Defender sensor (DataCollection) performing system queries and launching native tools
description: Multiple PowerShell processes executed scripts from C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\... (GUID.ps1). Those PowerShell instances invoked native utilities (net.exe, auditpol.exe) and spawned csc.exe (C# compiler) / cvtres.exe. Parent processes include SenseIR.exe / MsSense.exe (Defender components). Behavior (PowerShell -> native Windows tools, dynamic compilation) is consistent with both automated telemetry/forensic collection and common attacker post-exploit reconnaissance or in-memory loaders.

mitre.description: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell execution. Discovery: Account and system information queries (net.exe / auditpol.exe).

indicators_of_compromise: powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy AllSigned -NoProfile -NonInteractive -Command & 'C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\<GUID>.ps1'
Accounts observed: system, local service, network service, aniket
notes: PowerShell child of SenseIR.exe / MsSense.exe and scripts located under Defender's DataCollection folder — likely Defender telemetry/collection activity. However the same behavior (PowerShell invoking native tools and compiling code) can be used by attackers, so monitor and validate with EDR artifacts and defender telemetry.

title: Dynamic compilation observed: PowerShell -> csc.exe -> cvtres.exe
description: Multiple events show powershell launching csc.exe to compile code (cmdline files under C:\Windows\SystemTemp and ServiceProfiles paths) then cvtres.exe. Dynamic compilation via PowerShell/Add-Type or on-the-fly compilation can be used for legitimate diagnostic/telemetry tasks (here associated with Defender sensor) but is a common technique used to run ephemeral/compiled payloads in memory.

mitre.description: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Use of PowerShell to compile and execute code via C# compiler (csc.exe).

indicators_of_compromise: powershell.exe invoked prior to csc.exe (see DataCollection ps1 path)
notes: Because the compiling actions are initiated by Defender-related processes (SenseIR/MsSense and DataCollection scripts), this is likely legitimate. If further evidence (unknown network connections, persistence artifacts) is found, escalate.

title: Signed-binary proxy execution observed (wevtutil, rundll32) — defender and system components performing manifest installs/updates
description: Numerous wevtutil.exe install/uninstall-manifest commands were executed by MsMpEng.exe and svchost.exe contexts (WindowsAppRuntime / Microsoft Defender manifests). Also multiple rundll32.exe calls for AppXDeploymentExtensions.OneCore.dll were observed. These are legitimate signed-binary proxy executions used by Windows and Defender during updates and appx operations. Attackers do abuse such LOLBins, but the parent processes and command-lines indicate expected product update/telemetry activity.

mitre.description: Signed Binary Proxy Execution: use of legitimate signed binaries (wevtutil.exe, rundll32.exe) to perform actions.

notes: Current evidence indicates Defender and Windows update operations. Only escalate if these LOLBins are observed with unusual parent processes (e.g., explorer.exe spawning wevtutil) or unexpected remote network activity.

title: Azure Guest Agent / VM guest operations observed (CollectGuestLogs, BfeToolWin8, WindowsAzureGuestAgent)
description: Multiple processes related to Azure VM guest operations were created: WaAppAgent.exe, CollectGuestLogs.exe, WindowsAzureGuestAgent.exe spawning BfeToolWin8.exe and FindVolume.exe. These entries indicate VM/agent maintenance and log collection activity, not attacker behavior in the provided timeline.

mitre.description: Azure guest agent and log collection activity (platform/management operations).

notes: These entries align with Azure VM guest agent and diagnostic activities. No action required unless unexpected external connections or unknown binaries are observed.

title: PowerShell-driven local account and audit reconnaissance (multiple invocations)
description: Multiple instances where PowerShell (launched by SenseIR / system context) spawned Windows built-ins to enumerate accounts, audit policy and drivers. This pattern (powershell -> net.exe / auditpol.exe / driverquery) is consistent with post-compromise discovery activity used to map accounts, privileges and logging configuration prior to lateral movement or privilege escalation.

mitre.description: Account and system information discovery via built-in Windows utilities (net.exe accounts, auditpol.exe, driverquery) executed from PowerShell

indicators_of_compromise: powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy AllSigned -NoProfile -NonInteractive -Command ... C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\*\*.ps1
notes: PowerShell commands reference PS1 files under the Defender ATP DataCollection folder and include Get-FileHash checks. The PowerShell -> net.exe / auditpol / driverquery sequences are high-fidelity discovery activity; confirm whether these particular PS1 scripts are legitimate Defender sensor activities or attacker-supplied scripts executed via the sensor context.

title: PsExec service observed (PSEXESVC.exe) — evidence of remote service execution
description: A process entry shows services.exe launching PSEXESVC.exe. PSEXESVC.exe is the service component used by PsExec (Sysinternals) and is strongly associated with remote command execution and lateral movement. Presence of PSEXESVC.exe on a file server during the compromise window indicates likely lateral execution from another host or deliberate deployment of PsExec.

mitre.description: Remote command execution / lateral movement via PsExec-style service creation and SMB/admin share mechanisms

notes: Confirm whether PsExec was used legitimately by administrators. Check service creation events, service start timestamps, SMB session logs, source IP/host that created the service, and presence of PsExec on other endpoints. If malicious, pivot immediately to hosts that have open admin SMB sessions to azuki-fileserver01 at that time.

title: Frequent use of csc.exe (C# compiler) and on-disk temporary compiles following PowerShell — potential in-memory/compiled payload execution
description: Multiple sequences show PowerShell or other system processes invoking csc.exe to compile code (csc.exe /noconfig /fullpaths @"...cmdline") followed by cvtres.exe and temporary RES*.tmp outputs in C:\Windows\SystemTemp. csc.exe is a signed Microsoft binary but can be abused to compile and load C# payloads at runtime (LOLBIN pattern). The timing/parent chains (PowerShell -> csc.exe -> cvtres.exe) during the compromise window is suspicious and warrants collection of the compiled artifacts and cmdline files.

mitre.description: Abuse of signed Microsoft tools (csc.exe) to compile and execute code; PowerShell used to drive compilation and execution

indicators_of_compromise: PowerShell invoking csc.exe (see associated PS1 paths)
notes: Collect the referenced cmdline files (e.g., C:\Windows\SystemTemp\b2qpjv3y\b2qpjv3y.cmdline) and any RES*.tmp and CSC*.TMP artifacts. Extract compiled assemblies and inspect for malicious payloads. If Defender/IR sensor legitimate tooling compiled code as part of collection, validate via hashes; otherwise treat as potential attacker activity.

title: Frequent Defender/IR sensor PowerShell data-collection executions (DataCollection PS1 with file-hash checks)
description: Repeated PowerShell invocations load PS1 scripts from C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\... with inline Get-FileHash checks prior to dot-sourcing the PS1. These are consistent with Defender / SenseIR telemetry and investigative collection. They are relevant context for the timeline (they appear throughout the compromise window) and may explain some PowerShell/csc activity, but they do not by themselves prove malicious activity.

mitre.description: PowerShell used to load local PS1 scripts; in this dataset these scripts are Defender DataCollection artifacts with Get-FileHash verification.

log_lines: 2025-11-24 18:21:28.669472+00:00,system,ProcessCreated,azuki-fileserver01,"""SenseIR.exe"" ""OfflineSenseIR"" ""1328"" ""eyJ...""","powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy AllSigned -NoProfile -NonInteractive -Command "& { ... Get-FileHash 'C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\...\0e371fa0-...\.ps1' -Algorithm SHA256; if (!($calculatedHash.Hash -eq '37f8a9faa2213ae969a69519bc75d08e75f26152007ff4e08602be54666855a4')) { exit 323;}; . 'C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\...\0e371fa0-...\.ps1' }"""
indicators_of_compromise: Multiple SHA256 values present in Get-FileHash comparisons (example: 37f8a9fa...855a4, 3fe7adad...3530d, etc.)
notes: These Defender/IR script executions likely originate from the security product and may explain many PowerShell activities. However, attackers sometimes leverage or mimic security tooling — validate the PS1 file contents for unexpected commands, and cross-check hashes against the vendor/IR baseline. If any DataCollection PS1 hash does not match vendor-supplied signatures, escalate.

title: Suspicious PowerShell Command Involving Encoded Base64 Payload
description: Multiple instances of PowerShell executing with the '-NoP -W Hidden -File' parameters, and an encoded base64 payload, which is a common indicator of obfuscated macros or scripts used in lateral movement, command and control, or payload execution.
indicators_of_compromise: Encoded PowerShell command string with base64 payload
notes: Consider correlating with other signs of lateral movement or C2 communications. The encoded command suggests a possible attempt to obfuscate malicious activity.

title: Suspicious Network Communications via PowerShell with curl
description: Multiple logs of PowerShell invoking 'curl.exe' to POST or GET data to external IP '78.141.196.6' at port '8880' with consistent base64 encoded parameters, suggesting possible data exfiltration or command and control activity.
indicators_of_compromise: Repeated curl commands to suspicious IP
notes: This activity correlates with known C2 channels or exfiltration via legitimate tools like curl, often used in lateral movement or persistence

title: Repeated Use of Legitimate Process and Commands for Reconnaissance
description: Multiple instances of process chains involving 'net.exe' commands ('net.exe accounts', 'net.exe share', 'net.exe view') and 'ipconfig /all', which could indicate reconnaissance activities targeted at uncovering network shares, user accounts, or network configuration.
indicators_of_compromise: Repeated net.exe commands targeting admin shares and network discovery
notes: Such command sequences are typical pre-lateral movement activities, especially when combined with exfiltration or privilege escalation tools

title: Malicious staging via PowerShell and LOLBins (certutil, attrib)
description: User 'fileadmin' used PowerShell to hide a staging folder, download a PS1 from an external IP with certutil, and run it. An encoded PowerShell command fetched a second payload (svchost.ps1) into System32.

mitre.description: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell. Also used LOLBins (certutil) for ingress (T1105) and artifact hiding (T1564.001).

notes: Folder hiding with attrib (+h +s) indicates covert staging (T1564.001).

title: Persistence and HTTP C2 via curl masquerading as Microsoft-WNS
description: Attacker installed persistence via HKLM Run to execute svchost.ps1 and used curl to beacon and pull tasks from 78.141.196.6:8880 with a Microsoft-like User-Agent.

mitre.description: Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder. C2 over web protocols (T1071.001) using curl (LOLBIN).

log_lines: 2025-11-22 02:10:50Z fileadmin: "powershell.exe" -> "reg.exe" add HKLM\...\Run /v FileShareSync /d "powershell -NoP -W Hidden -File C:\Windows\System32\svchost.ps1"
notes: HTTP polling cadence suggests established C2. Block and investigate egress to 78.141.196.6.

title: Network share discovery and data staging from local file shares
description: Attacker enumerated users, admin groups, shares, and a host path, then copied data from local share roots (C:\FileShares\...) to a hidden CBS directory for staging.

mitre.description: Network Share Discovery. Also group discovery (T1069.001/002) and account discovery (T1033).

notes: No execution from UNC paths observed. Activity shows enumeration and mass file collection from locally hosted shares.

title: Archiving and exfiltration of collected data to file.io
description: Collected share data was compressed with tar and exfiltrated via curl uploads to file.io.

mitre.description: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage. Data was staged and archived (T1560.001) before upload.

notes: Block or investigate outbound HTTPS to file.io and retrieve transaction logs.

title: Credential dumping from LSASS using ProcDump (pd.exe) and exfiltration
description: Attacker used pd.exe to memory-dump LSASS and exfiltrated the dump via file.io.

mitre.description: OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory

notes: Immediately expire credentials that may have been present in LSASS. Hunt for reuse.

title: Event log clearing to cover tracks
description: Attacker cleared multiple Windows event logs using wevtutil, likely to impede forensic analysis.

mitre.description: Indicator Removal on Host: Clear Windows Event Logs

notes: Acquire volatile artifacts and EDR telemetry to compensate for cleared logs.

title: System and network reconnaissance
description: Recon commands executed for system info, accounts, groups, and active connections.

mitre.description: Account Discovery; also T1082 (System Information), T1016 (Network Config), T1049 (Network Connections).

notes: Sequence aligns with hands-on-keyboard post-compromise triage.

title: Likely RDP interactive session preceding malicious activity
description: Presence of rdpclip.exe and interactive shell components at compromise start suggests RDP session for 'fileadmin'.

mitre.description: Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol

notes: Pivot to DeviceLogonEvents/SigninLogs to confirm source IP and authentication method. No execution from UNC paths observed.
